snippet: Lawmakers in the two states changed bills promoted as religious freedom measures and criticized as anti-gay, to remove the most contentious language, though in different ways.
abstract: Lawmakers in Indiana and Arkansas approve new legislation to remove most contentious language from religious freedom measures that were widely perceived as anti-gay, albeit in different ways; critics say new versions are not enough to prevent discrimination, while conservative supporters see new versions as hopelessly watered down.

byline.original: By MONICA DAVEY, CAMPBELL ROBERTSON and RICHARD PÉREZ-PEÑA
byline.contributor: Monica Davey reported from Indianapolis, Campbell Robertson from Little Rock, Ark., and Richard Pérez-Peña from New York.

lead_paragraph: Lawmakers in the two states changed bills promoted as religious freedom measures and criticized as anti-gay, to remove the most contentious language, though in different ways.

headline.main: Indiana and Arkansas Revise Rights Bills, Seeking to Remove Divisive Parts
headline.print_headline: After Rights Clash, Two States Revise Legislation
